p.s: Description of Yersinia pekkanenii sp. nov.

Yersinia pekkanenii (pek.ka.ne′ni.i. N.L. gen. masc. n. pekkanenii in honour of the late Professor Timo Pekkanen, who was a veterinarian and former head of the Department of Food and Environmental Hygiene in the Faculty of Veterinary Medicine of the University of Helsinki. He made a substantial contribution to the development of scientific research of food hygiene in Finland).
Cells are Gram-negative rods of 1–3 µm diameter and are non-motile, oxidase-negative and catalase-positive.
Positive for urea hydrolysis and ONPG utilization.
Ferments d-xylose, cellobiose, trehalose, l-arabinose and glucose.
Does not ferment adonitol, sorbose, salicin, raffinose, glycerol, inositol, sorbitol, melibiose, rhamnose or sucrose.
Negative for lysine decarboxylase, ornithine decarboxylase, Voges–Proskauer reaction, lipase and indole production.
Grows on blood, tryptic soy, MacConkey and nutrient agar at 25–37 °C.
Produces pinpoint colonies on blood agar at 30 °C in 24 h.
16S rRNA gene sequence similarity with Y. aldovae CIP 103162T is 99.9 %.
The type strain is ÅYV7.1KOH2T ( = DSM 22769T = LMG 25369T), isolated from a lettuce sample.
Reference strains are Å125KOH2 and ÅYV25K1, isolated from water and soil samples, respectively, suggesting an environmental habitat.
